area_name: Gully Wall, AKA Dr. Seuss Wall, The

content.description: Follow the hand sized crack up and over the blocky feature

Scramble up into the scoop on the corner under the roof with the crack.  There is a blocky feature on the wall in the back that serves as an undercling handhold and gear placement.  Make a long reach out to the lip of the roof to find the thank god jug.  From here you can try and place gear above or below or just execute the handful of thuggy moves required to surmount the lip and stand up.  Good finger sized gear awaits the rest of the route, which is significantly easier.
content.protection: Gear to 2 " shares chain anchor with Mouse in Bucketland
content.location: On the left side of the Gully Wall AKA Dr. Seuss Wall.

content.description: Climb the water polished rock leading up from the waterside.  A variety of different routes offer 5.10 to 5.12
content.location: Located below the road West of the Gully.  Look for a set of chains just off the edge of the road.

content.description: Pulling the roof is the business.  The rest is easier but still engaing with a tricky ending.
content.location: Left of Little Woo.  The bolt line tackling the small blocky roof and wandering up the slabby corner system above.

content.description: Work through the boulder problem at the second bolt which may be .12a on its own.  Chug up the vert face on better holds to reach the arete.  Follow this up and around to the right onto the slab to finish.  This one will wake you up at the end!  Established on St. Pattys Day.
content.location: At the far left side of this wall is a light gray horseshoe-shaped face with what look like radioactive symbols bolted randomly onto the rock. Begin by stepping off a boulder onto the steep rock on the far left edge of this wall.

content.description:
This route climbs the obvious chimney feature just to the right of the light grey horse shoe-shaped feature at the far left side of the Gully Wall.

Begin with opposing side pulls and scamper up into the wide cleft.  Clip bolts on the right but keep in mind this is a stemming route, the wall to your left is full of good foot placements and the occasional hand hold.  Continue up the chimney until it ends and you are forced onto the face.  The trickiest moves on the route guard a good ledge with a hand crack in a corner leading up to the chains.
content.location: The obvious chimney at the left end of the Gully Wall

content.description:
I’ll tell you what’s cool’s feistier younger brother

Pitch 1: 5.8 with a V4 Boulder problem in the first 15 feet.  5 bolts.

Pitch 2: 5.8, 5 bolts.

Pitch 3: 5.8, 6 bolts.

Pitch 4: 5.10- with a well protected crux after the fourth bolt.  6 bolts.

Very doable for anyone who can climb 5.10 or even 5.9 in the area

With a 70m rope we rappelled from the 4th to 3rd anchor and were able to barely rappel to the ground from there
content.protection: Bolts to chain anchors at every pitch.
content.location: On the far left side of the Dr. Seuss Wall and a bit up the gully.  To the left of Mouse in Bucketland in the scree gully. The only multi pitch nearby so if you find multiple anchors you got it.

content.description: Wander up discontinuous cracks to the steeper roof section.  Pull through and continue up the slabby section to the chains.
content.protection: Gear to 2-1/2", one bolt, chain anchor
content.location: Left side of the Gully Wall AKA Dr. Seuss Wall.

content.description: Scramble up the broken corner to the ledge, a piece of gear may ease tensions here.  Traverse left a bit to gain the corner and begin your way up.  Good gear and fun climbing involving a bit of stemming.
content.location: The major dihedral just left of the Gully.

climbs.name: The Last Pale Light in the West

content.description: The crux of this route is clipping and moving away from the 2nd bolt.  There is a good ledge about halfway up the route that splits it into two distinct sections.  The second half, on the reddish headwall is really cool though it wanders back and forth between a choss-filled crack on the left and the jugs on the finish of The Judge, the route to the right.  Good route.
content.location: At the far West end of this formation.  This is the farthest left route, 50 feet up the hillside.  There is a decent trail and platform built for climber and belayer.  Nice work!

content.description: Begin on the steep prow and climb up under the roof and into the wide cleft.  A little 3-dimensional problem solving leads into the steep V-groove and the crux.  Burl through the hardest moves and up onto the beautiful red headwall to find tricky 5.11 climbing to the anchors.  A brilliant and difficult route!
content.location: Just right of Last Pale Light in the West, coming up through the steep cave and blasting up the red headwall.

content.description: Going through the small roof section at the bottom is the crux, but well protected by bolts.  The route eases significantly by the time the gear starts going in.  A fun climb on good stone.
content.protection: 4 bolts and gear to 3", chain anchor.
content.location:
Left of the Big Brag and 25 feet right of the Gully.

Tackles the overhang via a short prow leading up under the roof.

content.description:
Start from either the ledge or the road (easy climbing to the first bolt). Face holds on the right and side pulls on the left get you through a few clips then into some sinker jams. Figure out the first bulgey section on decent feet, jams, and locks to a good rest before the last little bit. Battle the upper part using the crack or other features to the chains.

The lower section of the crack needs a little gardening and cleaning to make this route better. Birds, their poop, and eggs may be present.

6 bolts to anchors with chains.
content.location: On Dr. Seuss Wall, look for a vegetated crack with a few bulges protruding near the top.

content.description: A slabby chute-like climb with ample bolts.  Good for beginners and new leaders.  Fun
content.location: Left of Rip tide and roughly above the Riverside toprope.

content.description: Initially the climbing is pretty easy, though you may want to place a piece before the first bolt at 20' up.  Getting through the roof is a little bit tricky but well protected by bolts.  The crux is likely the 40' of crack climbing and gear placing above.  The last third is cruiser though gear is sparse with one bolt toward the end.
content.protection: 4 bolts and small gear to 1".  Chain anchor
content.location: This route begins by following a right slanting crack up a slabby face.  As the route steepens, pass 3 bolts leading out a short roof to a crack system above.  Place gear until the crack peters out.  Clip one last bolt and mantle a ledge to find the chains.

content.description: 6 bolts with one open shut anchor and one carabiner. Super cool flake climbing for the first 3 bolts, then traverses left. Crux is around bolt 5 getting to 6th bolt, having to find some slightly hidden holds. After the 6th bolt do a quasi mantle up to the top and trust your feet to get to the chains. A little dirty so wear your helmet!
content.location: Park at the access point to lower canyon granite. Scramble down the trail and walk along the road for 5-10 minutes. Dr. Suess wall should be just a bit past the guard rail in the middle of the road. Climb up a grassy ledge to find the belay spot. Should be towards the left of the wall.

pathTokens: Gully Wall, AKA Dr. Seuss Wall, The
